docs.lead_paragraph: LOW unemployment, rapid economic growth, the lowest rate of inflation in decades: what more could a Federal Reserve chairman want? Nothing, if the views of a respectful Congress, an enthusiastic financial industry and a worshipful press are to be taken at face value. In fact Alan Greenspan is in a bind, trapped between the public's expectation of perpetual economic bliss and evidence that even the Goldilocks Economy is not immune to the ailments of inflation and recession.

headline.main: Economic Scene; The Fed is trapped between expectations and reality.

docs.abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column on Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's dilemma, trapped between public's expectation of perpetual economic bliss and evidence that even current economy is not immune to ailments of inflation and recession; by conventional measures, American economy is overheating; Fed has not made pre-emptive strike on inflation for variety of reasons, but it will doubtless act sometime this year, barring evidence that economy is cooling on its own; predominant view is that delay will compound both pain of taming inflation and risk of overshooting; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A four-day rally in stocks fizzled yesterday amid renewed fears that strong economic growth may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. Investors received little consolation from the latest economic reports -- the March index of leading economic indicators and a monthly retail sales report -- which showed further evidence of the robust growth that was glimpsed in last week's reports.

headline.main: 4-Day Rally Comes to Halt On Fear of Rate Increases

docs.abstract: Dow Jones industrial average declines 45.09 points, to 9,147.57; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slips 6.57 points, to 1,115.50; Nasdaq composite index falls 13.95 points, to 1,864.91; graph; chart (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Foundation Health Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its workers' compensation unit to Superior National Insurance Group Inc., a unit of the Superior National Corporation, for about $290 million in cash so it can focus on its managed-care services and improve profit. Foundation Health said in February that it planned to sell the unit, which is called Business Insurance Group Inc. The unit, which reported a loss for 1997, writes workers' compensation insurance for businesses. Superior National, based in Calabasas, Calif., sells workers' compensation insurance in California and Arizona. The shares of Foundation rose $2.625, to $32.125, and Superior National's stock rose $1.50, at $22.

headline.main: FOUNDATION HEALTH TO SELL UNIT FOR $290 MILLION

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Lauch Faircloth, a Republican, has been running attack ads in his home state of North Carolina that castigate the leading candidate for the Democratic senatorial nomination, John Edwards, for being a lawyer. ''He makes millions suing people,'' the commercials contend. Since the vast majority of senators share Mr. Edwards's occupation, it may surprise them to know that their colleague from North Carolina regards the job as suspect. Mr. Faircloth, a farmer-businessman, is trying to make voters think their health insurance costs have risen because of Mr. Edwards's success in winning personal-injury cases.

headline.main: Topics of The Times; A New Political Pariah

docs.abstract: Topics editorial comments on attack ads being run in North Carolina by incumbent Republican Sen Lauch Faircloth castigating John Edwards, leading candidate for the Democratic senatorial nomination, for being lawyer (S)

Goldstein, M.D., says that it is ''difficult to justify'' insurance payments for Viagra ''considering that impotence is not a life- threatening condition'' (letter, April 30). Although impotence itself is not life threatening, it is a core problem for men treated for prostate cancer.

docs.lead_paragraph: For a Republican mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani has maintained surprisingly good relations with labor, even gaining the endorsement of the citywide labor federation last year, but those relations have entered a rough patch in recent weeks. The immediate cause for this souring was the city's decision to lay off 905 workers at city-owned hospitals -- a move that labor leaders saw as a sharp reversal of Mr. Giuliani's practice of largely shunning layoffs during his first four years in office.

headline.main: For Giuliani, Ties to Labor Turn Shaky With Layoffs

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Health Panel Seeks Sweeping Changes in Fertility Therapy'' (front page, April 29): I applaud the New York State Task Force on Life and the Law's efforts to regulate advanced fertility technologies. However, the panel's concern for the unborn and newborn child should not exclude the health care needs of infertile couples. The panel's recommendation to deny mandatory insurance coverage for infertility is punitive and should be reconsidered. Since infertility is caused by myriad medical problems, it needs to be treated as any other serious health condition. NANCY BERLOW Plainview, N.Y., April 30, 1998 The writer is president of Long Island Resolve, an infertility support group.
docs.abstract: Nancy Berlow letter on Apr 29 article on New York State task force proposals to regulate advanced fertility technologies (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Almost every workday for the last several weeks, Horace Edwards Kelly Jr., a San Quentin inmate sentenced to die, has sat shackled to his chair in Marin County Superior Court, observing a jury hearing that will determine whether he is mentally competent enough to be executed for fatally shooting two women and a boy in 1984. On rare occasions, his gaze drifts over the courtroom, a complacent smile broadening across his face. Most of the time, though, his eyes remain fixed on a spot beyond the 12 jurors and 4 alternates listening to testimony about his damaged brain.

headline.main: Hearing on Death Row Inmate's Competency Bogs Down

docs.abstract: Hearing to determine whether Horace Edwards Kelly Jr is mentally competent enough to be executed for three 1984 slayings has been dragging on in Marin County, Calif, forcing postponement of execution (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT would have been an odd evening, that's for sure. Hugh Hefner, the man who put women in bunny costumes and set the wheels of the sexual revolution in motion for millions of Americans, and Gloria Steinem, the crusading leader of the women's movement, were supposed to go on a blind date a few decades ago, as Mr. Hefner tells it.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is now well accepted that the diamond-shaped blue pill is a wonder of the modern age, a restorer of hope to the hopeless, the ultimate growth stock and, yes, in the blink of the CBS eye, already a tired joke at cocktail parties. But Viagra is now ascending to a yet loftier status, that of Topic One for America's would-be intellects, as seemingly everyone from subway to salon waxes ponderous or salacious or both in the rush to instant analysis. Bob Guccione, the publisher of Penthouse, proclaimed that Viagra will ''lead to new relationships between men and women and undercut the feminist agenda.'' He said it will ''free the American male libido in the same way the Pill did.''

headline.main: The Nation: Thanks a Bunch, Viagra; The Pill That Revived Sex, Or at Least Talking About It

docs.abstract: Viagra has become Topic One in America, and everyone seems to have an opinion, or a joke, about it; problem of impotence is not new, nor are supposed remedies offered over the centuries; but Viagra is much easier to use, and it seems to be marking another step toward open discussion of taboo subjects; most estimates are that at least 30 million men suffer from impotence, but numbers are higher if problem is defined more broadly; three is also blurring of line between real need and sexual enhancement; photos (M)
